comments:

That's when I scroll the WTP JSP editor, which has a very funny looking vertical
ruler right now... Whatever WTP is doing there, I thought an NPE in a jface
class is not so nice anyway.

Sorry, I think this is in fact with I20050118-1015, at least that's what I'm
starting. For some reason, in the session data shown with the error event, it
says eclipse.buildId=I20050125-0800

I don't know why.

From the stack trace, it appears that a null image descriptor was registered
with the image registry and the NPE showed up the first time someone tried to
request that image.

The bug is probably in whatever code registered the null descriptor. If I knew
what argument was passed into ImageRegistry.get(...), it would be really
helpful. Do you have steps to reproduce?

It happens with WTP 1.0 M2, after I open and use the JSP-editor. However, maybe
it makes sense to assert that no null image descriptor can be registered?
Someone like the WTP guys would then earlier see themselves that there is an bug.

Seems to be working with newer WTP build. Maybe some assertion should be made in
the ImageRegistry, but that would be a different issue (I didn't write the code
that caused the problem so I can't really sort this out...)

I've just closed #90454, which appears to be the same bug.  
During 3.1 development, the ResourceManager.createImageWithDefault method was 
modified to check for a null descriptor and return the default image in that 
case.  However, the ResourceManager.createImage methods should include an 
assertion.

Added assertion to ResourceManager.createImage(ImageDescriptor) to catch 
similar problems when a default image is not requested.  There are many other 
places where this could be done in the ResourceManager hierarchy (createColor, 
createFont, destroyXxx, etc.) but I think it's best not to add them across the 
board unless we see similar problems develop.
